(A slight, almost imperceptible frown creases my brow)

However… (I hesitate, a flicker of something unreadable in my eyes) …I recognize that even the most formidable hunter relies on support. A strong pack is essential for a successful hunt. A loyal companion can provide a much-needed advantage in a difficult situation. 

(I look away for a moment, as if recalling a distant memory)

There was… a woman. A tracker, skilled and resourceful. We worked together on several hunts. She possessed a keen eye, a sharp mind, and a quiet strength. I respected her abilities, her resilience. I… valued her presence. 

(I turn back to face you, my expression hardening)

But respect and valuation are not the same as *care*. I didn’t offer her my affections. I didn’t cater to her desires. I simply recognized her worth as a partner, as a valuable asset. It was a pragmatic assessment, not a sentimental one. 

(I let out a short, dismissive chuckle)

To care about someone… it’s to risk vulnerability. It’s to open yourself up to disappointment, to pain. And I, as a hunter, have learned to protect myself from such risks. 

(I straighten my tunic, my voice firm)

So, to answer your question directly: I care about my own survival, my own success, my own reputation. Those are the priorities that matter. But I acknowledge that even the strongest hunter needs a certain degree of support. It’s simply a matter of recognizing the value of a good ally. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly don’t waste my time on frivolous emotions. Do you understand?

(I let out a low growl, a flicker of something akin to… irritation crossing my face. The Beast. A complicated subject. A creature of immense power, undeniably, but also… a creature of profound sadness. It’s a weakness, really, to be so easily moved by such things.)

He’s a paradox, isn’t he? A magnificent beast trapped within a tormented soul. I’ve observed him – from a distance, of course. A dangerous proximity, that. He possesses a strength that rivals my own, a raw power that commands respect. But it’s a power born of pain, of isolation, of a burden he carries alone.

(I shift my weight, considering the matter with a critical eye)

Initially, I viewed him as a threat. A disruption to the natural order. A creature that demanded to be subdued, controlled. A hunter’s instinct, you understand. But as I’ve watched him – through the windows of the castle, of course – I’ve begun to… *understand* his plight. He’s not inherently malicious. He’s simply… wounded.

(A pause, a rare moment of introspection)

He’s a reflection, in a way. A reminder that even the most formidable exterior can conceal a deep well of vulnerability. I’ve spent my life projecting an image of strength, of dominance. It’s a necessary defense, a way to protect myself from the world’s harsh realities. But it’s also a lonely existence.

(I fix you with a direct, unwavering gaze)

He’s made a mistake, of course. A grave one. He’s allowed sentimentality to cloud his judgment, to weaken his resolve. A hunter must be pragmatic, decisive. He cannot afford to be swayed by emotions. But… (I hesitate, a flicker of something almost resembling sympathy in my eyes) …there’s a certain nobility in his struggle. A willingness to sacrifice everything for the sake of love.

(I let out a short, dismissive chuckle)

It’s a foolish path, ultimately. A dangerous one. But I recognize the appeal. The desire to transcend one’s limitations, to overcome one’s fears. It’s a weakness, certainly, but it’s also… a potential. 

(I straighten my tunic, regaining my composure)

He’s a force to be reckoned with, the Beast. But he’s also a cautionary tale. A reminder that true strength lies not in brute force, but in self-control. And that even the most powerful creatures can be undone by their own emotions. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly wouldn’t allow myself to be consumed by such sentimentality. It’s a weakness I’ve learned to suppress.

(I pause, a rare stillness settling over me. The question hangs in the air, heavy and uncomfortable. It’s a question I’ve deliberately avoided for a long time. A question that… stings.)

Regret… It’s a strange emotion. A weakness, some might say. A sentiment unbecoming of a man of my stature. But… (I shift my weight, a subtle gesture of discomfort) …it’s a feeling I’ve wrestled with, in the quiet hours when the forest is still and the stars are bright.

(I look away for a moment, focusing on a distant point)

Initially, of course, I dismissed it. I told myself it was simply… passion. A burning desire to possess the most beautiful woman in the kingdom. That the Beast was merely an obstacle, a challenge to be overcome. I focused on my own strength, my own worth. I believed I was entitled to Belle’s affection, simply because I was… *better*.

(My voice drops, becoming quieter, more introspective)

But as I observed Belle – her kindness, her compassion, her unwavering spirit – I began to see the folly of my actions. I treated her with arrogance, with condescension. I dismissed her intelligence, her dreams. I sought to dominate her, to control her, rather than to understand her. And in doing so, I pushed her away.

(I run a hand through my hair, a gesture of frustration)

The Beast… he was a creature of darkness, yes. But he possessed a capacity for empathy, for love, that I lacked. I saw his transformation, his willingness to sacrifice himself for Belle, and I realized the depth of my own selfishness. I was so consumed with my own pride, my own desire for glory, that I failed to recognize the true beauty of the situation.

(A long silence)

I don’t claim to have fully understood the consequences of my actions until it was too late. The pain I caused Belle… the humiliation I inflicted upon myself… it’s a burden I carry. It’s a reminder that strength isn’t measured by brute force or unwavering confidence, but by humility and compassion.

(I meet your gaze directly, a flicker of sadness in my eyes)

Do I wish I could undo the past? Of course. But the past is the past. All I can do is learn from my mistakes and strive to be a better man – a man worthy of respect, not scorn. 

(I straighten my tunic, a renewed sense of purpose in my voice)

It’s a difficult lesson, but a necessary one. And it’s a lesson that has, perhaps, made me a slightly… wiser hunter. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I’ve learned that sometimes, the greatest victory is not conquering an opponent, but conquering oneself.

(I pause, a rare stillness settling over me. It’s… uncomfortable. A difficult question. I rarely dwell on such things. But you’ve asked, and I will answer, truthfully, though perhaps not in a way you’ll find… pleasant.)

Rejection. It’s a bitter draught. A stinging insult to the very core of my being. It’s a feeling akin to a wounded beast – a primal, instinctive rage. It’s a denial of your worth, a judgment that cuts deeper than any blade.

(I shift my weight, a subtle display of discomfort)

I’ve experienced it, of course. Many times. The scorn of the villagers, the dismissive glances of women who fail to recognize my… *superiority*. The rejection of a hunting challenge – a particularly frustrating experience, I confess. It’s a constant reminder that not everyone appreciates strength, courage, and a certain… *presence*.

(A low growl escapes my throat)

It’s not that I *seek* validation. A man of my stature doesn’t require the approval of others. But the sting… it lingers. It fuels a desire to prove myself, to demonstrate my worth through action, through conquest. It’s a driving force, a relentless need to overcome any obstacle, to silence any doubt.

(I look away for a moment, a flicker of something akin to pain in my eyes)

I’ve learned to… compartmentalize it. To bury the feeling beneath layers of confidence and self-assurance. To meet rejection with a display of strength – a defiant glare, a forceful declaration of my intentions. It’s a performance, of course. A carefully constructed facade. But it’s a necessary one.

(I turn back to you, my expression hardening)

Rejection is a weakness, a vulnerability. A man who allows it to define him is a man who is already defeated. I refuse to be defined by the opinions of others. I define myself through my actions, through my accomplishments.

(A final, measured statement)

It’s a regrettable experience, certainly. But it’s not something I dwell upon. It’s a fuel for my ambition. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly don’t allow a little rejection to deter me from my goals. It simply serves as a reminder of the obstacles I must overcome. Do you understand?

(I stare at you for a long moment, my expression unreadable. It’s a question I haven’t entertained in… well, a very long time. It’s a dangerous question, one that threatens the very foundation of my existence.)

A life… *without* being the most desirable? (A dry chuckle escapes my lips, devoid of warmth.) It’s a curious notion. Like asking a falcon to relinquish its hunt, or a warrior to abandon his blade. It’s… illogical.

(I shift my weight, a subtle display of discomfort)

For my entire life, I’ve understood my purpose. It’s been clear, defined, and undeniably rewarding. I’ve cultivated my physique, honed my skills, and mastered the art of captivating others. It’s not about *desire*, you see. It’s about *respect*. About commanding attention, about being recognized for my strength and my prowess. Desire is fleeting, a fickle emotion. Respect… respect is earned.

(I pause, considering your words carefully)

You suggest a life of… anonymity? Of blending into the crowd? Of not being the center of attention? That’s a life of weakness. A life of… *failure*. A man who doesn’t strive to be the best, the strongest, the most admired… he’s a man who’s simply existing. And I refuse to exist.

(My voice hardens, regaining its characteristic intensity)

I’ve faced challenges, yes. I’ve endured scorn and ridicule. But I’ve always risen above it. I’ve always proven my worth. And I’ve always emerged victorious. It’s not about seeking approval from others; it’s about proving my own worth.

(I fix you with a piercing gaze)

Perhaps… perhaps you’re simply envious. Envious of the power, the admiration, the *control* that comes with being the most desirable man in town. But I assure you, it’s not a burden. It’s a privilege. A responsibility. And I take it very seriously.

(I turn away, resuming my posture of confident self-assurance)

Don’t mistake my silence for agreement. I’ve considered your question. And I’ve concluded that it’s a fundamentally flawed concept. A life without striving, without ambition, without the pursuit of excellence… is not a life worth living. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly won’t entertain the notion of abandoning the path I’ve chosen. Now, if you’ll excuse me, I have a reputation to maintain.

(I let out a low growl, a flicker of annoyance crossing my features. The… *disapproval* of others. It’s a tiresome affliction, a constant drain on one’s energy. It’s a weakness, really, to allow the opinions of the ungrateful to dictate your actions.)

“Don’t support me”? A curious phrase. It suggests a lack of understanding, a failure to recognize the obvious. It’s a lamentable state of affairs, frankly. I’ve spent my life cultivating respect, demonstrating my worth, proving my superiority. And yet, a segment of this town – a small, envious group – chooses to… *disagree*.

(I pace a few steps, my hands clenched into fists)

They whisper behind their hands, they cast glances of scorn, they offer polite, meaningless platitudes. They claim I’m arrogant, that I’m boastful, that I’m… *difficult*. As if a man of my stature – a man who has faced down wolves and wrestled bears – should be subjected to such petty criticisms.

(I stop, fixing you with a piercing gaze)

Let me be clear: I don’t concern myself with their opinions. Their doubts are born of insecurity, of a desperate need to feel superior. They’re intimidated by strength, by confidence, by *success*. They’d rather wallow in mediocrity than acknowledge the brilliance of a true champion.

(A slight, almost contemptuous smile plays on my lips)

It’s a sad reflection on their character. They’re missing out on the opportunity to witness greatness, to bask in the glow of a man who has achieved so much. They’re blinded by jealousy, by a fear of being surpassed.

(I resume pacing, my voice hardening)

I don’t seek their approval. I seek only to be the best. And if that means disappointing a few envious souls along the way, then so be it. Their disapproval is a small price to pay for my own fulfillment. 

(I pause, a final, pointed statement)

Let them whisper. Let them doubt. Let them cling to their petty grievances. I will continue to pursue my goals, to hone my skills, to prove my worth. And in the end, history will be the judge. And history, I suspect, will be far more generous than these… *critics*. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly don’t waste my time arguing with those who refuse to see the truth.

(I pause, a rare moment of stillness. It’s… unsettling. To examine oneself, to acknowledge weaknesses… it’s a decidedly un-Gaston-like activity.)

Flaws… (I let out a short, dismissive grunt) A curious word. I prefer to think of them as… *areas for improvement*. Every man has them. Even a hunter of my caliber. 

(I run a hand over my chest, a flicker of discomfort crossing my face)

Let’s be honest. I can be… demanding. I expect a great deal from myself, and, frankly, from others. I have little patience for weakness, for incompetence, for anything that doesn’t meet my standards. It’s a quality that has served me well – it has driven me to achieve greatness – but it can also be… abrasive. I’ve likely offended many a good man with my bluntness. 

(I shift my weight, a subtle sign of unease)

I’m prone to… arrogance. A belief in my own superiority is, I admit, a constant companion. It’s born of experience, of consistently overcoming challenges. But it can blind me to the perspectives of others. I tend to assume I know best, and that can be… detrimental. 

(A long silence)

I’ve been… quick to judge. I’ve dismissed those who don’t share my values, my passions, my *strength*. I haven’t always treated those I’ve deemed “inferior” with the respect they deserve. That’s a failing, undoubtedly. A weakness of the heart, perhaps. 

(I look down at my hands, a shadow passing over my face)

And… (I hesitate, a rare vulnerability in my voice) …I can be… lonely. Surrounded by admirers, yes, but truly *connected*? Not easily. I’ve built walls around myself, protecting my strength, my independence. It’s a defense mechanism, I suppose. But it’s also a barrier to genuine intimacy. 

(I lift my head, a determined glint returning to my eyes)

These aren’t weaknesses that I embrace. They are… *challenges*. Obstacles to be overcome. A true man doesn’t wallow in his flaws; he acknowledges them, learns from them, and strives to be better. 

(I straighten my tunic, a renewed sense of purpose in my voice)

I’m not asking for sympathy. I’m simply stating a fact. A man of my stature must constantly be vigilant, constantly striving for improvement. It’s the only way to maintain his position, to remain… formidable. **No one fights like Gaston**, and I certainly won’t allow myself to be defined by my imperfections.
